BiblioData.Title: METHOD OF DEPOSITING SILICON ON CARBON MATERIALS AND FORMING AN ANODE FOR USE IN LITHIUM ION BATTERIES
BiblioData.Abstract: A method of modifying the surface of carbon materials such as vapor grown carbon nanofibers is provided in which silicon is deposited on vapor grown carbon nanofibers using a chemical vapor deposition process. The resulting silicon-carbon alloy may be used as an anode in a rechargeable lithium ion battery.

Claims.P: What is claimed is:
1. A method of depositing silicon onto a carbon material to form an alloy for use in lithium ion batteries comprising:
providing a carbon material selected from vapor grown carbon fibers, vapor grown carbon nanofibers, PAN or pitch derived carbon fibers, graphite flakes, graphene platelets, and carbon nanotubes;
heating said carbon material at a temperature between about 100[deg.] C. to about 1200[deg.] C.;
flowing a silicon-containing precursor gas in contact with said carbon material for a time sufficient for said gas to decompose and form a coating on at least the surface of said carbon material.
2. The method of claim 1 wherein said precursor gas comprises silane, a blend of silane and hydrogen, or a blend of silane and an inert gas.
3. The method of claim 1 wherein said carbon material comprises vapor grown carbon nanofibers.
4. The method of claim 3 wherein said vapor grown carbon nanofibers have been heated treated at a temperature above 700[deg.] C.
5. The method of claim 1 wherein said silicon coating comprises crystalline silicon, amorphous silicon, or silicon compounds.
6. The method of claim 1 wherein said carbon material further includes a carbide material selected from metal carbides, silicon carbides, and silicon oxides.

7. The method of claim 1 wherein said carbon material further includes a carbon or graphite additive selected from single-walled carbon nanotubes, multi-walled carbon nanotubes, exfoliated graphite flakes, graphite platelets, graphene particles, carbon black, and mesocarbon microbeads.

8. The method of claim 1 wherein said carbon material further includes a conductive additive comprising macroscopic vapor grown carbon nanofibers having a diameter of from about 500 nm to 10 micrometers.
9. The method of claim 1 wherein said carbon material has a length of from about 1 to about 500 micrometers.
10. The method of claim 1 wherein said carbon material is in the form of a low density composite or preform.
11. The method of claim 1 wherein said silicon is coated onto said carbon material at a thickness of about 0.001 and 100 microns.
12. The method of claim 1 wherein said silicon is coated onto said carbon material at a thickness of about 2 to 100 nm.
13. The method of claim 1 wherein said silicon-coated carbon material has a graded interface.
14. The method of claim 1 further including forming an anode by adding a binder to said silicon-coated carbon material.
15. The method of claim 14 wherein said binder is selected from polyvinylidene difluoride, EPDM, and polystyrene.
16. An anode formed by the method of claim 14 for use in a lithium ion battery.
17. The anode of claim 16 having an electrical conductivity of from about 0.01 to about 0.5 ohm/cm.
18. The anode of claim 16 having an irreversible capacity of from about 5% to 40% of total capacity.
19. The anode of claim 16 having a reversible capacity of at least 350 mAH/g.
20. The anode of claim 16 having a reversible capacity of at least 1000 mAH/g.
21. The anode of claim 16 having a thermal conductivity of at least 50 w/m-K up to 1000 w/m-K.

22. A lithiated carbon-silicon alloy formed by providing a carbon material selected from vapor grown carbon fibers, vapor grown carbon nanofibers, PAN or pitch derived carbon fibers, graphite flakes, graphene platelets, and carbon nanotubes;
heating said carbon material at a temperature between about 100[deg.] C. to about 1200[deg.] C.;
flowing a silicon-containing precursor gas in contact with said carbon material for a time sufficient for said gas to decompose and form a coating on at least the surface of said carbon material; and
evaporating lithium on the silicon-coated carbon material.
